The "inner dual cone" and "dual cone" constructions in mathlib (Set.innerDualCone and PointedCone.dual) require the cone to be a subset of an inner product space over R\mathbb{R}R. However, the construction can be done in much more generality, as follows.

Let MMM be a module over an arbitrary ordered semiring RRR, and let C⊆MC \subseteq MC⊆M be a pointed cone (i.e. an R≥0R_{\geq 0}R≥0​-submodule of MMM, where R≥0R_{\geq 0}R≥0​ is the subsemiring of RRR consisting of the nonnegative elements). Then we may define the dual of CCC to be the set

C∗={f∈M∗ ∣ f(v)≥0 for all v∈C}⊆M∗,C^* = \{f \in M^* \, | \, \text{$f(v) \geq 0$ for all $v \in C$} \} \subseteq M^*,C∗={f∈M∗∣f(v)≥0 for all v∈C}⊆M∗,

where M∗=Hom⁡R(M,R)M^* = \operatorname{Hom}_R(M, R)M∗=HomR​(M,R) is the dual module. It is not hard to see that C∗⊆M∗C^* \subseteq M^*C∗⊆M∗ is also a pointed cone.

If R=RR = \mathbb{R}R=R and MMM is an inner product space, then there is a canonical isomorphism between MMM and M∗M^*M∗, and thus the dual cone of CCC can be thought of as a subset of MMM rather than as a subset of M∗M^*M∗. This recovers the constructions that are currently in mathlib.

Many important theorems about cones can be stated in this generality. For example, one formulation of the Minkowski–Weyl theorem is that if MMM is a finite-dimensional vector space over an ordered field RRR and C⊆MC \subseteq MC⊆M is a pointed cone which is finitely generated as an R≥0R_{\geq 0}R≥0​-module, then so is C∗C^*C∗. I know @Yaël Dillies is working on this (#Is there code for X? > Main Theorem of Polytope Theory ).

Unfortunately, the supporting hyperplane theorem (which, in this formulation, can be stated simply as C=C∗∗C = C^{**}C=C∗∗) seems to require MMM to be a finite-dimensional vector space over R\mathbb{R}R. But this assumption can be relaxed to RRR being any ordered field if CCC is finitely generated as an R≥0R_{\geq 0}R≥0​-module (this is Farkas' lemma).

I think that this generality is quite important, because it is common to work with polytopes and cones over Q\mathbb{Q}Q and Z\mathbb{Z}Z. (For one thing, this makes them computable.) I have created a github issue: #19738. However, I am not sure how to proceed with actually refactoring the existing library to work in this generality, or whether this is even a good idea. Does anyone have any thoughts?
Would it make sense to abstract away from M∗=HomR(M,R)M^* = \text{Hom}_R(M,R)M∗=HomR​(M,R) to a pair of modules M,NM,NM,N with a perfect pairing?
Of course this excludes MMM of infinite rank. But at the same time it brings back a symmetry, so that C∗∗=CC^{**} = CC∗∗=C will typecheck again.
The perfect pairing approach is also the one used in docs#RootPairing
Yeah, that would probably be a good idea.

The dual can be defined with respect to any pairing (yielding an antitone Galois connection between the pointed cones in MMM and the pointed cones in NNN), though many of the theorems will only hold for perfect pairings.
Also, the concept of dual can be made even more general by replacing the subsemiring R≥0R_{\geq 0}R≥0​ with an arbitrary subsemiring, though I am not sure if this has any use.

For example, let L/KL / KL/K be a field extension and let VVV be a vector space over LLL. Then for any subspace W⊆VW \subseteq VW⊆V over KKK, one may form the space

{f∈V∗ ∣ f(v)∈K for all v∈W}⊆V∗\{f \in V^* \, | \, \text{$f(v) \in K$ for all $v \in W$}\} \subseteq V^*{f∈V∗∣f(v)∈K for all v∈W}⊆V∗

where V∗=Hom⁡L(V,L)V^{*} = \operatorname{Hom}_L(V, L)V∗=HomL​(V,L). Is this concept useful?
I don't see an immediate use for it. So I would stick to R≥0R_{\ge0}R≥0​ for now.

By the way, here's a coordinate-free and topology-free proof of (one direction of) Minkowski–Weyl for cones by a "deletion-contraction" argument. I can't find this in the literature, but I'm sure I'm not the first person to write this down. It is the result of simply taking the existing proofs using Fourier–Motzkin elimination and removing the coordinates from them. This is similar to how the exchange property in linear algebra can be thought of as removing the coordinates from Gaussian elimination.

Hence, www is in the k≥0k_{\geq 0}k≥0​-span of (B′∩H+)∪(C′∩H)∪(C∩H)=(B∩H+)∪(C∩H)(B' \cap H^+) \cup (C' \cap H) \cup (C \cap H) = (B \cap H^+) \cup (C \cap H)(B′∩H+)∪(C′∩H)∪(C∩H)=(B∩H+)∪(C∩H), as desired.

Lemma.

Let WWW be a finite dimensional vector space over an ordered field kkk. Let v1,…,vn∈W∗v_1, \ldots, v_n \in W^*v1​,…,vn​∈W∗ and let H1+,…,Hn+⊆WH_1^+, \ldots, H_n^+ \subseteq WH1+​,…,Hn+​⊆W be the corresponding half spaces (i.e. Hi={w∈W ∣ ⟨vi,w⟩≥0}H_i = \{w \in W \, | \, \langle v_i, w \rangle \geq 0\}Hi​={w∈W∣⟨vi​,w⟩≥0}.) Then C=H1+∩⋯∩Hn+C = H_1^+ \cap \cdots \cap H_n^+C=H1+​∩⋯∩Hn+​ is a finitely generated pointed cone.

Proof

We use induction on nnn. If n=0n = 0n=0, then C=WC = WC=W. Since WWW is finitely generated over kkk and kkk is finitely generated over k≥0k_{\geq 0}k≥0​ (by 111 and −1-1−1), we conclude that C=WC = WC=W is also finitely generated over k≥0k_{\geq 0}k≥0​, as desired.

Suppose n>0n > 0n>0. Let C~=H1+∩⋯∩Hn−1+\widetilde{C} = H_1^+ \cap \cdots \cap H_{n - 1}^+C=H1+​∩⋯∩Hn−1+​. By the inductive hypothesis, C~\widetilde{C}C is a finitely generated pointed cone; let B⊆WB \subseteq WB⊆W be a finite generating set of C~\widetilde{C}C.

Also, define the hyperplane Hn={w∈W ∣ ⟨vn,w⟩=0}H_n = \{w \in W \, | \, \langle v_n, w \rangle = 0\}Hn​={w∈W∣⟨vn​,w⟩=0}. Then HnH_nHn​ is itself a finite dimensional vector space over kkk. By the inductive hypothesis, the set C∩Hn=(H1+∩Hn)∩⋯∩(Hn−1+∩Hn)C \cap H_n = (H_1^+ \cap H_n) \cap \cdots \cap (H_{n - 1}^+ \cap H_n)C∩Hn​=(H1+​∩Hn​)∩⋯∩(Hn−1+​∩Hn​) is an intersection of n−1n - 1n−1 half spaces in HnH_nHn​, so it is a finitely generated pointed cone; let B′⊆HnB' \subseteq H_nB′⊆Hn​ be a finite generating set of C∩HnC \cap H_nC∩Hn​.

We claim that the finite set (B∩Hn+)∪B′(B \cap H_n^+) \cup B'(B∩Hn+​)∪B′ generates the cone CCC. Since B′B'B′ generates C∩HnC \cap H_nC∩Hn​, it suffices to prove that (B∩Hn+)∪(C∩Hn)(B \cap H_n^+) \cup (C \cap H_n)(B∩Hn+​)∪(C∩Hn​) generates CCC, which is guaranteed by the previous lemma.

Theorem (Minkowski–Weyl).

Let V,WV, WV,W be finite-dimensional vector spaces over an ordered field kkk and let ⟨⋅,⋅⟩ ⁣:V×W→k\langle\cdot , \cdot\rangle \colon V \times W \to k⟨⋅,⋅⟩:V×W→k be a perfect pairing. Let C⊆VC \subseteq VC⊆V be a finitely generated pointed cone. Then

C∗={w∈W ∣ ⟨v,w⟩≥0 for all v∈C}⊆WC^* = \{w \in W \, | \, \text{$\langle v, w \rangle \geq 0$ for all $v \in C$}\} \subseteq WC∗={w∈W∣⟨v,w⟩≥0 for all v∈C}⊆W

is also a finitely generated pointed cone.

Proof.

Since CCC is finitely generated, there exist v1,…,vn∈Vv_1, \ldots, v_n \in Vv1​,…,vn​∈V such that C=span⁡k≥0{v1,…,vn}C = \operatorname{span}_{k_{\geq 0}}\{v_1, \ldots, v_n\}C=spank≥0​​{v1​,…,vn​}. Then C∗C^*C∗ is the intersection of the half spaces Hi+={w∈W ∣ ⟨vi,w⟩≥0}H^+_i = \{w \in W \, | \, \langle v_i, w \rangle \geq 0\}Hi+​={w∈W∣⟨vi​,w⟩≥0}, so it is a finitely generated pointed cone by the previous lemma.
